instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
Hi to all...820-01041 no liquid spill...3 usb ports stuck on 5v, the other port totally dead

Because of a small journey, I’ve ask a friend of mine, technician, to change the controller corresponding to the dead port

I don’t know why, I have changed all 4 controller

now i have 5v@0,269 on all 4 ports

According to this guide

[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3215_Bootup_Sequence[/URL]

I confirm that

i have all ldo's...

i have PPDCIN_G3H
i have TBA_VDDA (PPCHGR_VDDA)
i have PM_EN_P3V3_G3H (NC_CHGR_EN_VR1)
i have PP3V3_G3H

i can't find in schematic PP1V2_G3H_SMC_VDDC or PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC
i can't find in schematic PP3V0_G3H_AVREF_SMC or PP3V0_S5_AVREF_SMC
if it is PP3V0_G3H_RTC, i have 3,3v

i can't find SMC_RST, if it is TP_CHGR_SMC_RST_L, i have 1,7 and not 3v

if i connect the upper left or right port to my mac m1, i receive the message

"impossible to use accessory"

if i try to connect the others two ports, nothing happen

please help and sorry for my bad english!

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
Do you get 1V1 LDO BMC on the corresponding powered port?
Test connecting charger to all ports.

Are you using original 87W charger?
Machine turns on with battery connected?

What is the exact PPBUS_G3H voltage?
If missing, remove F7000/1 and check C7050 voltage.

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
CC1/2 pins change the voltage, according which direction is connected the charger on the corresponding port.

Check diode mode on all big coils and compare with good board, or refference table.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://openboarddata.org/?a=showboardsolutions&bpath=laptops/apple/820-01041[/URL]
Don't forget L9080/580.

Try to put the machine in DFU using wire method.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)#/media/File:SOC_FORCE_DFU_Jumper.jpg[/URL]

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
Do you know what these values for coils mean???
Don't get confused man.
Internal specifications of the coils, have nothing to see with diode mode (or ohm resistance) to ground.

If T2 gets all SLPS2R and AWAKE required voltage, it should go into DFU.
Be sure to use all steps to enter DFU correctly.

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
"asked me to check all coils in diode mode"
We use the coils as test points for the secondary power supplies output!

What do you expect to get in diode mode (or ohm scale), measuring between a coil pins?
The coil is a short in DC mode!

Personally I prefer to solder a small switch (with 5-10cm wires) over the force DFU pads.
Machine should enter to DFU after 5-10s, starting with the switch closed.
If not, force it off (power button) and try again.
Sometime I got in DFU maintaining the switch closed when i forced the machine off.
I fight with an A1949 two days until I got in DFU.
This is not as easy as you think.
Apple did a "good job", for its interest.

Some peoples claimed they couldn't get in DFU with original Apple cables.
Even the macOS installed in the host machine may impede to detect the target machine correctly with AC2.

"0v on r6941 (UPC_PMU_RESET)"
Good enough, we don't want the machine in reset state.

Be aware to solder correct CD3215 chips, with the same code termination; C00, A12, B03 not interchangeable.
You can solder and test one by one.

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
Did you solder the CD3215 chips with correct termination?
C00, A12, B03 are not interchangeable.

If U7800 delivers all required SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages, board should enter DFU.
If not, there is a problem with T2 chip or communication through corresponding DFU port.
If you replaced all CD3215 chips and checked all ports, probably T2 is the culprit.

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
OL means open line, no connection.
May be caused by incorrect solders under CD3215 chips, or broken traces.
I recommend to check directly on J3300 and JB500 in diode mode.

S-UEM2 tool is better for this purpose.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-d&sca_esv=579431573&hl=es&sxsrf=AM9HkKlGYzdloF_GM-8-va03FYRA2oRoQQ:1699276747809&q=s-uem2&tbm=isch&source=lnms&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjgkbaXu6-CAxX6UKQEHa1yDCUQ0pQJegQIDRAB&biw=1536&bih=630&dpr=1.25[/URL]

You can also test replacing USB-C cables.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://es.aliexpress.com/item/1005004265288371.html?src=google&src=google&albch=shopping&acnt=439-079-4345&slnk=&plac=&mtctp=&albbt=Google_7_shopping&albagn=888888&isSmbAutoCall=false&needSmbHouyi=false&albcp=20330803848&albag=&trgt=&crea=es1005004265288371&netw=x&device=c&albpg=&albpd=es1005004265288371&gclid=Cj0KCQiAuqKqBhDxARIsAFZELmI26FYprMOpE-J_m-sVlYsVlHrSKsGhLA317Wk0sblqp3IoGyGeqr0aAisLEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds&aff_fcid=f9e2e3d40ef2432da7a5ecfee56c6860-1699276835447-05094-UneMJZVf&aff_fsk=UneMJZVf&aff_platform=aaf&sk=UneMJZVf&aff_trace_key=f9e2e3d40ef2432da7a5ecfee56c6860-1699276835447-05094-UneMJZVf&terminal_id=aa99aa154f2b4fe2bee8a5be8dfc1523&afSmartRedirect=y[/URL]

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
S-UEM2 will give high readings (24xx) for not connected pins (NC) as normal.
But will indicate the wrong values with up/down arrows; like 24xx instead of 293.

When you have doubts, is better to manually check corresponding pins in diode mode directly on the board.

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
All CD3215 chips must be present on board.
T2 (SMC part) must "talk" with each one to find the powered port, then will start the communication with the charger.

On each side you have a primary and secondary chip.
Not sure how Apple used this terminology, as U3200 boots first (on left side) from U2890.
U3100 boots from U3200 through UART lines.
You may have problems with Q3200, or its traces.

Similar theory applies to UB400/300.
Not switching at all to 20V on right side, may be caused by UB090 problems.

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
J3300 is the left connector; look at the board as in normal working position, mounted in the housing.
However, this is not important here.

As I said, check all resistors around U3100/200 and their traces/solders.
Just in case, replace Q3200.

On the right side (UB300/400), try reflashing UB090.

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
You should tahe the readings when the charger is connected to corresponding port.
Can also use an o-scope to compare TBT SPI signals, according with the powered ports.

U2800 and UB000 are also connected to TBT SPI chips and can affect them.
May suspect UB000, as none of its ports switch to 20V.
You should also remove and check (out of board) each dual MOSFET paired with CD3215 chips; except the working one.

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
i have taken the reading with the charger connected to the corrisponding port...

i have oscope but i'm not able to use it...

so i have a board 820-00840....with same mosfet...q3100 and q3200...so i could change 2 mosfet what do you think

threads.title: [HELP]a1990 820-01041 NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message: You can change them, but should be better to check them anyway.
